reviewText:
Early Access Review

What used to be a fantastic game has recently been turned into garbage. Read on for more information.
When I first bought rust about a year ago I wasn't surprised by the amount of bugs the game had. It was Alpha and I expected this kind of thing. I was surprised by the fact that even though this game had bugs, (don't forget the hackers as well) this game was quite enjoyable. The main thing of the game is that your stuck on a huge island and you have to build a shelter and defeat other players to survive, along with going to 'rad towns' and getting supplies, (which let me tell you is not always easy when you have a ton of rad bears and wolves coming at you). The game gets pretty addicting and fulfilling especially when you get guns and start raiding other players. There was food and cold but you didn't have to drink water to survive and the game was pretty simple. The other players are the problem, and many of the reviews you read trash this game not because of the reasons I am about to tell you, but because they felt the game was too hard. Most of those reviews are written by players who've played 100 hours or less. Don't read those, they haven't played long enough. The real reason this game is terrible has nothing to do with the way the game is (or was, (read on), the real reason is because of the developers. See this game is probably better than most I have played, until about 6 months ago. See when I first bought the game a year ago this game was not updated until 6 months later, and the developers said that for six months they were developing a newer version, and better version,  and that the old version was now called Legacy. Well for the next six months and up until now that newer version is no newer version at all. Legacy which was the older version that I loved and enjoyed has been torn into a buggy mess that has real updates once a month. Oh yes you will be told they update about once a week, but when you look at what they are updating every week you'll see the crap they are doing. You see all sorts of things like 'lets make this chicken have better textures' or 'look at this new bandage were designing'. Eventually about once a month they'll have an update that will 'fix a whole bunch of bugs and add many new things'. Those updates every month made the game worse, and eventually they started going somewhere when they added all these building updates. You could make all sorts of cool buildings, but then guess what the dev's told us they wanted us to explore and not build, they released a brand new update that limited our building. Then everyone started complaining and they told us 'were hobbyists'. These dev's know nothing of what they are doing, they release patches that ruin the game and they take away things we like to do, like building. Eventually this whole 'new version' which was released 6 months ago in replace of the legacy version was scrapped again! Now they have a Brand new version which was just released in January. The updates they are releasing seem way more promising than they did before, but seriously this game has been out for a year. A whole year it took to get a better version! Take a game like H1Z1, which was also just released in January. The game which is in Alpha right now when released had an enormous amount of bugs. The amount of bugs have now been reduced so much within a month that the game is very much playable and provides us with more 'items' in the game within a month than rust has added within a year. In fact Rust has not added really any 'new' items to the game at all. This new version is still being built up to the amount of the Legacy version. Either way Rust has been rebooted several times now and if I were them I would just scrap the whole thing and go back to the Legacy version and start updating that version again. This game used to be a hell of a game, and now all we have to look forward too is another version of 'chicken textures updates'. H1Z1 looks like a much more promising game as the devs are responding to us much faster than the devs of Rust. If I were you i'd save your money on Rust but dont forget about Rust. This game is still in Alpha and if the devs can manage it maybe we can look forward to a Beta with more features and less bugs. I love this game, but H1Z1 looks way more promising.


Dont buy the game until Beta, and even then check the reviews again.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI played quite a bit during Legacy, and have over 1,000 hours in Experimental/New Rust. This game is truly my favorite game on the Steam market. Rust is not for ragequitters or sensitive types. You will die by cold, hunger, thirst, drowning, fall damage, animals, and most of all, other players. You will lose everything you spent hours, maybe even days, to acquire. You may even get harassed by other players. Nearly everyone has these experiences at some point in Rust. As a primarily solo player, I absolutely love the thrill and challenge of surviving in Rust. I'm pretty terrible at PVP, but Rust notably has some of the best PVP. Building in Rust is unmatched by other early access games (including H1Z1 and ARK). Building in Rust has to be strategic if you want to survive the night. Not to mention, it is extremely time consuming (and sometimes difficult, depending on the population size of your chosen server), to gather enough resources to build and fortify your base. Rust is hostile, vulgar, and full of trolls, but it is also challenging and beautiful. It's that one game I will always recommend to my friends. It's not an easy game to play solo, especially if you're on a high pop server where there are likely multiple clans or groups that PVP and raid. My only word of advice for anyone who is new to Rust is don't give up. You're going to rage in this game sometimes, but don't quit. Survival was never meant to be easy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What the hell happened to Rust?

Before I continue, let me tell you my Rust story. I've tried DayZ and realized that game is going nowhere (let's hope it will start to move on toward something good). So 've jumped right in Rust, and boy, did I fall in love! We had a beautiful server (Rust Survivor), a great community and it was all about having fun. There were bandits, workers, builders, server police, airdrops, even one admin was a living jukebox that used to visit during night to ease the tension. I've played almost thirty happy hours of Rust version that's called 'legacy version' right now. Thirty hours may appear like nothing to you, but in my life - thirty hours is a whole lot of dedication, believe me.

Anyway... I've faded away because of my obligations and when I've decided to reinstall it, I've figured out my beloved server and people are all gone, legacy version is hacker and cheaters infested heaven turned hell and Rust's experimental version became officially the new and 'stable' one. OK, I said to myself, time to move on.

You may call me an 'old fart', but after playing one hour of new stable (formerly known as experimental) version of Rust, all I can say is... WTF?

Game is over the top buggy, clunky and badly compiled, failing where previous version succedeed. There's no more atmosphere, no more fun and certainly no more addictiveness that was the thing why I've loved Rust in the first place.  Certainly, they've added a lot of new things since legacy, but the general impression is they've manage to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the game in so many possible and impossible ways.

Why they didn't keep legacy up and running with good antihack protection, I will never understand, but Rust at this particular moment is a good game gone bad with an experimental stable version that's way too experimental for me to have fun. I'm not in the mood to spend my precious gaming hours figuring out how to get ride of thousand and one bug that I occur and I will not tolerate it because I've seen Rust in a better shape.

So, as of now, as a Rust fan - I don't recommend you to buy this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Status:
Now is the time to start picking this game up, with the new engine overhaul and massive updates coming weekly.

This game right here is one of the most promising sandbox games currently out there, with little competition, and one of the best Early Access games to follow right now. The talented team, with king Garry from Garry's Mod in the front are constantly delivering plenty of updates right now that you can watch in the blog where they report everything.[playrust.com]

The old engine (legacy) is what is being showcased in the videos/screenshots on the steam page right now, and it's probably the version many people played when they first bought the game. Now it's way, way different and better and it's getting more work done.

Not to mention, the graphic and random terrain generation overhauls are superb.


The gameplay:
In rust, the focus is on three things:
- base building
- resource gathering and hoarding
- base raiding

If any one of those is something you are interested, you'll have a blast.

What you want to have to get the best out of the game:
- friends
- time around the clock

The experience is hardcore, and basically requires you to play it regularly to keep what you build.


Basics of the game:
The map is either custom made or randomly generated, and really varied.

There are other players on the server, and when you log out your character sleeps where he is and can be killed/looted.

You have needs like hunger, thirs, cold, wetness, comfort and more to be added.

You gather resources by utilising tools on the resources in the map (tress, rocks) and hunting animals.

You build bases in a modular fashion, where you place foundations, then pillars, then walls, then doorways, then doors, then locks on those doors. Bases modules can be square or triangular. Door locks can be key based (where you craft the key to the door) or pin code based.

You can destroy buildings by hitting them with axes/pickaxes (it takes maybe an hour to do so on high upgrades) or use explosives like C4 detonation or rocket launchers (that are hard to craft or find).

Bases modules can be upgraded by hitting them with tools and using up resources in your inventory. I think the stages at the moment are: twigs, woods, stone, iron, reinforced. Each of them can withstand more punishment before going down.

There are some objects called cupboards that authorize building in an area around them. Meaning if you click on them, only if you're authorized you can build around it (to prevent grief building around a base you own).

There are plenty of weapons and gunplay is fairly hardcore. Need to aim down sights. Shotguns, tommyguns, pistols, AKs, bolt actions, all of them really artisanal and rusty looking.

Most items have durability and degrades / can be repaired.

There are random air drop events around the map where a rare package gets dropeed with supplies and weapons. Encourages PvP.

Friendly fire is of course enabled.

When you die, you spawn to a bed you own (there is a 200+ second cooldown on respawn on bed atm) or you can just spawn randomly along a coast.

You can request a friends bed so that you can spawn on it through a command. (so you can meet up with friends if you just joined on a server).

There are radiation zones, with buildings that spawn loot barrels, but you receive damage over time if you are not protected in those areas.

You have to research items if you want to KNOW how to craft them. Either find the blueprint as a drop, or research at a research bench for a chance to gain the items knowledge, and destroy it in the process.

There are plenty of flavourful items in the game right now, like paintings, guitars, signs, campfires, roofs.

Roleplay as much as you want, since people are generally really fun to play with. Set up a shop, be a militant general, be a hunter, be a city manager, be a lone wolf, be a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Whatever you want, you can play however you want.

People start naked, and if you deactivated censoring you can see pinis in front of your eyes while you're hurled up in your base.

All characters are male now, for good reason. You have a random race and skin color when you sign in that's tied to your steam profile and cannot be changed.



So much ♥♥♥♥ to do, so much fun to have.
A great time sink for the hardcore survival lovers.
Do whatever it taeks to survive.
Gather some friends and play the night away.

9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer: I have had RUST before it came out on steam more than two years ago in Closed Alpha. I was heavily into base raiding and PVP. If you plan on playing in carebear PVE servers, skip this review. But here are my two cents about its current status otherwise. Take it with a grain of salt if you will...

----------------------------------

Yes: The developers are more active now than ever.
Yes: It gets frequent content updates.
Yes: Game's a blast when playing with a group.
Yes: Graphics are looking more spectacular now than ever.
No: Glitching/hacking still exists. (It's just the nature of this type of game, more on that later)
No: Game feels like a clunky mess after being rebuilt numerous times. (It was very responsive originally.)
No: Janky new mechanics are a hindrance in a situation where you need to be responsive against other players.
No: The game is STILL in Alpha Early access after two years. (Not unusual if you look at DayZ, but still.)
No: Updates are slowly transitioning towards content only updates, with less and less technical updates from Garry. (Which is what this game needs in my opinion; more on that below.)

----------------------------------

With that being said, the two biggest issues is that the game has been rebuilt from the ground up constantly, and the hacking/glitching issues.

----------------------------------

1. The game used to be responsive, though with the introduction of each rebuild it turned into a more and more unresponsive mess. Movement and responsiveness are huge factors in a game where aiming and positioning are the two most important things when PVP comes into play. This leads to unsatisfying deaths feeling like your character should be moving one way but turned out to be kind of glued into a certain spot. More often than not the game looks like a testing ground for Garry to practice his coding, the game worked as is initially, and now too much time was spent redoing the entire thing just for it to look nicer and feel smoother.

----------------------------------

2. With hacking and glitching overall: It's hard to blame Facepunch Studios on this one, as they have taken a lot of measures to prevent hacking and glitching, but it's such a huge issue in these types of games. You can't stop someone who constantly works against you in coming out with paid/private hacks when they have a price incentive for customers who are willing to skip the games week grind if it means killing a top tier base and being at the 'end game' instantly, along with having the edge and never dying. Dying and losing your stuff is a huge net loss, both morally and game wise.

Find a hacker in CS:GO? Report him and move on, you only wasted 30 minutes of your time, and you most likely never see him again. Hackers in DayZ/RUST? Your entire weeks worth of work is down the drain. With all the anti cheat improvements, RUST is the type of game where even one hacker/glitcher getting through can ruin the game for an entire server. Though with the type of game its hard to even identify one, granted if you're offline and your stuff is just gone with the doors/walls still up, you'll have no person to point at. Even with wallers/aimbotters, it's hard to tell with no spectate option, unless you get shot in the head 5 times instantly. But a game such as this can't be expected to have a spectate option. Like I said its just the nature of this type of game.

----------------------------------

I expect this to be in Alpha for another year honestly, if it ever leaves Early Access is another question entirely. I honestly can't recommend a purchase at this point knowing that the formula is said and done, and if you're looking for a game like RUST, then there are others way ahead of the curve. I feel like a games experience shouldn't come down to an admin trying to police a server, which is what happens here. The game itself should be designed with preventative features like that in mind. Games like these apply a human band-aid in the form of admins, who can be more often than not, biased, and given/give special treatment, though its hard to argue when you own the server. Still the thought of an in-game admin is archaic and should be left in the past along with the games that lacked proper mechanics that required a person to log in and manage a game.

----------------------------------

All in all, I feel like the game just isn't worth it. The current direction its headed reminds me of ARK:SE, which isn't a bad thing, but ARK:SE already got there first. Even worse is that Facepunch Studios is working on the next Garry's Mod, which means Garry will focus his time on the next project and leave this one up to his community managers and content staff to finish up the main bits, while he adds a shiny new effect here and there.

----------------------------------
----------------------------------
----------------------------------

For all old rust players out there reading, the game was a definite blast when it first came out. Now it's just a complete mess of a project trying to play catch up after struggling to redefine the game so many times. For new rust players, skip this one and go for another game in the genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are a LOT of joke reviews on Rust currently circulating in the community. Let me be a serious voice in the crowd.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW. THIS GAME IS THE VERY EXAMPLE OF WHY EARLY ACCESS GAMES ARE A BAD PURCHASE.

**EDIT 7/17/2014**
I came back to this game after months of inactivity, to see if it has changed enough for me to want to play it. It has not. This game is every bit as bad as it was to begin with. This time around, I chose a server with 0 population and played for 5 hours in blissful peace. No one to bother me, only survival. I amassed quite a wealth of items and gear and was just starting to get to the point where I could decently explore my surroundings without dying. I logged off inside of my home, determined to come back later.

24 hours later, I logged on to find myself stranded in the middle of nowhere, with nothing on my person. I tracked down my 2-level house, nestled in the mountains near the coast, and found it utterly destroyed and my defenses wrecked. Someone had found my home while I was logged off, destroyed everything I had spent my time building and collecting, killed my unconscious avatar, and stolen every single thing inside my home that was not nailed down. I feel cheated and frustrated. There is no point to this game, it seems to be lacking development for being early access, the community is still awful, and it will only punish you for purchasing it. Please do not buy this game and do not support it's development.

**************************
Currently Rust is in a VERY early alpha. The game is currently broken, in a number of different ways, and many people are having issues even looking for a server without crashing. From the standpoint of PvE, the game is entirely easy and it takes very minimal effort to stay alive past the first few days. Enemies and hazards are few and far between, and so laughably avoidable or killed that you genuinely don't have to worry, so long as you've had the foresight to build a hatchet or bow. Servers reset frequently with even small updates, though, so you will lose everything you've spent time building/collecting and it feels like pulling teeth. The game is also very rough and explains nothing, so your first few hours will be frustrating and hard without a companion who knows what they're doing, and that's IF you find a community server that doesn't have terrible latency or weird settings.

Now for the meat of this review: The community SUCKS. I'm not talking Oh
date: they have poor attitudes" sucks. I'm talking a HUGE percentage of hackers
recommended: modded servers that are intended to troll by making it impossible to get certain items
hoursPlayed: and outright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥gery on a level you have never seen. People always shoot you in the face first
voteText: no questions asked

votesHelpful: just for lulz. Often

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I picked this game up over the Steam sale hoping it would eventually go on sale however it didnt. I found a server with a low population and it was fun for a few days , but you have to spend hours at a game like this. So if you are a  casual player make sure you have friends who also play or you wont get anywhere in this game. If youve played  War Z ( now infestation) or Dayz or any of those types of games youll have an idea of the community in this game . some mean well but most just want to kill you for fun , or your loot. Thing is in this game you are never truly safe . Youll get raided non stop . to give an example 5 minutes prior to writing this review i relogged into rust only to find my base being held under seige by a group of players in kevlar. Even if you have a base players can put up ramps to get in or even break/blown down walls and doors Which i really dont find fun if you have spent so much time in the game , but hey it happens. Oh also i forgot to mention since the game is still farely new it patches quite frequently so servers will usually get wiped , so all your goods stored away and your bases will go poof and sometimes so will your crafting recipies. I also wouldnt recommend joining full servers because ppl will just run around as nomadic nudists killing you >_< and yes that had happened to me the first time i ever played this game. If youve got the time , dedication, and friends then be my guest and drop $20 on this . if you dont .... well i'd figure surviving out in the wilderness irl will be more fullfilling

**Update** so as of recently like last weekend , early April i decided hell ill play rust again . within a few minutes i ran into a player luckily i had a revolver but all in all he was friendly , we teamed up / talked over skype and eventually ended up with a 3 man team ! , however we switched servers the next day and started from scratch it wasnt so bad i suppose xD ,  we were playing on a no repair and instant craft server which will save u some time but wont save you enough , as i mentioned in my previous review this game takes alot of time to play ... i mean alot , youll find yourself getting sucked in with a mental to do list of crafting and there goes 1... 2... 3 hours . also you should understand in this game its raid and be raided blue prints are your friends , sleepers can be your downfall ,and c4 left in your base will be used against you , whoops let me get back on track. oh yes so time wise youll end up trading away a good weekend or your soul into this game to realize that you got raided , so what it happens its a part of the game but it truley does strike at your morale and begins to get really repetitive after awhile , i havent tried but id assume the only way to get anywhere in this game woudl be to join a clan and build a base with 4+ ppl , but 2 c4 can wreck your perfect base , my 3 man team ended up taking out a base with 4 sleepers and god knows how many sleeping bags but on our way back we were gunned down by 2 players , sad but true , Rust is very unforgivening so you have to be unforgiving back . also from what ive heard there are alot of hackers , is this statement legit ? hell idk my accuracy with guns in this game isnt top notch so id be a fool to accuse but be on your guard , good luck out there , and oh ... you might want to fork up that air drop signal b4 my buddies and i take it with force :) enjoy !

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After 800 (710 Correction) hrs of game play on Rust I am gonna write a very honest review on this

Personally I think it's the best Survival game ever. No Zombie, no Monster needed. People in game is bad enough which is amazing game system.

The more you play the more you get to it. It's best game addiction ever. Well.. Before we go deeper I think it's important to understand why are you playing game. I have my job and responsibility over family therefore game is something for relaxation not a second job!

Rust, game play is amazing, The game engine is not bad at all. Good game idea and system. Graphic is improving every update.

The more I play the more I found there is no balance in the game and it's purpose less.

good shooting and intelligent skill are not enough in Rust. It requires all your time and energy to become best in game or in order to survive. I play both Solo and Clients.

We manage to become best clients of snow region. We have over 30 people. Massive base and really well organize. At first it was fun cause you have friends and enjoy it but later on. It really became a second job. You need to maintain  the base and ♥♥♥♥. Many more problems comes like friends are not on-line together. You get kill  and robed by playing solo. Stuff got stolen in base. C4s has been use by no one know who used it. Doubt on each other. Blaming others cause not everyone work hard as others.

After hours of playing you soon will realized time is wasted for nothing. Server wipe every freaking month or at least two months. Depends on the update.

The point of the game is simply how to be a big mafia in Server cause you have all guns and C4s. Then raid others cause they mess with you then you get revenge by other cause you raid them. All your hours and hours of building base are now destroyed for nothing.

That is pretty much how Rust is.

The conclusion is if you have enough time to keep up with the game. This is totally perfect otherwise this is not what you are looking for :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow.

This game is so well designed. What an amazing accomplishment for Facepunch! The game has every element of a blockbuster survival game, and if I may say so, really showed DayZ how it's done. Even in alpha, I can already tell that this game is going to be the dominant survival game as the maps get bigger and respectively as Facepunch gets bigger and more innovative features are added. This project will definitely be their main focus and with such positive responses from the majority of players, how could it not be?

The game went right by taking what a survival game needs, challenges and obviously survival, and then brought it to the next level by allowing players to create their own bases / spaces and topped it off by requiring players to get resources to make those bases, which created a unique work and reward system. The game is designed with a narrow enough objective scheme (survival) to keep players on track while allowing them the room to make moral and creative choices. For example, you could help a new spawn or kill him and take his rock, LOL, or build a house here or maybe over there ;). Each blueprint, each won firefight, and each new floor to your house gives you that sense of adrenaline and accomplishment.

For me to have seen Facepunch grow as a company in the half decade I've been around here, as Garry's Mod was my first game on Steam and the game that made me decide I wanted to make games for a living, it's an incredibly inspirational and happy moment to see FP hit this one out of the park.

Addicting and perfectly designed - 10/10.

Go Garry, go! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There's so many things to say I barely know where to start. You might notice I got 900 hours of rust. I know this game since legacy, back when there were still zombies, so I've seen the developement of both the games and Facepunch. 3rd speaking of dev. I'm not gonna compare Legacy with the new Rust, since like people said before, they are kinda 2 different games (altough they are implementing always more stuff from legacy to Rust), so I will speak a bit of both.

Also let me say that I got this game recomended by a RL friend, who said there's a hype about this totally new and innovative game where you have to to survive in a world, eat, craft, hunt and build a house, where there's open PvP, made by a indie company, only catch, its an early access game. I thought I would still give it a try, have fun with my friend and help this company make their goal true, like crowd funding (which I kinda got to regret later). He stopped playing after a couple days.

Game developement itself:
Why is there even 2 versions of Rust? Because the original Rust (Legacy, new rust is just Rust) is a mess, engine and performance-wise. When Facepunch realized that the very foundations were crap, the best solution was to restart and do it right from the beginning instead of reprogramm everything. Rust has and always had troubles with bugs and performance, while graphically not being that impressive, specially in legacy. While the new rust definetively looks much better and can look great in full graphics, dont let the screenshots fool you, its still no skyrim like many ppl like to say, and noone plays like that as the fps drops to an unplayable state. I still always read from people with supercomps that get low fps and lags. Cheaters is another common problem specially in legacy. While they tried to fix that in Rust with EAC (EasyAntiCheat) which indeed did help at first (always more hackers find their way in), it also added half-dozen problems like EAC: DIsconnect, which added to the other half dozen problems of the game itself like some people getting black screen or others not finding server list, made alot of people not be able to play new Rust (me included) till recently and some still not to this day.It is really only recently that the game has become somewhat stable and playable, altough performance still lets wishes open, and usually for every change or fix, there come 3 new bugs which sometimes are released from dev test server even when obviously bugged. And they have changed the whole system so many times one would think they dont even know what they want, which direction they are heading, but it only keeps changing, not evolving (much atleast).Now I perfectly know this is still an EA game and in alpha, far from finished, but alot of people put alot of money in this game, and consindering how they handle developement, their attitude, and after all this time, one cant help but be disappointed in this game and company that call themself hobbysts while having made millions of an alpha game, often not listening to the suggestions of the people but implementing unnecessary stuff noone asked for.

Game itself:
Rust used to be something kinda new (only to be compared with DayZ that time I think) that, altough it originally had zombies (which got replaced later by red animals), is mainly caveman themed, with the radiated towns the only hint of some lost modern society, where your goal is to survive. But while one thinks this is kinda a fallout online, its just mainly a PvP game where you walk alot, because there's not much else to do after having built your fortress and having gotten all weapon and C4. Now while I had my share portion of fun in this game by creeping people in their houses at night with predator sounds (this game LIVES from voice chat and would be dullier than usual without) and laser sight, playing both alone and in groups, playing both pacifically and as raiding bandit, after building a base, getting raided, rebuilding, raiding, server wiped, building, raiding etc and repeating this process a hundred times (if you can't handle people bullying you and robbing/wasting your resources and time, dont play this, many people will backstab you), you can't help but feel this game needs much more to keep it interesting. While the thrill of the hunt (or being hunted while full of loot) can be exciting and make your heart race, there are so many other promising survival games that look better, are more interesting or devs work faster ( zombie survivals, dino surivals, mutant survival. I specially am interested in the co-op PvE of The Forest other EA games coming out, PvE in Rust is just kindergarten). So unless you like being a bandit, murdering and robbing other players, destroying their house and progress, eat their corpse and are ok with people doing the same to you, then I don't recommend paying for this game.

Now with all this said, since I cant sell or trade the game, I'll keep playing it from time to time, hoping that maybe in late future the game will finally be completed. Or until I completely loose hope and C4 it.

Update1: They added now Rocket Launcher. A fun addition, but that means the game becomes even more PvP and less survival. Now newbies and casual games will only survive"  12 hours instead of 24 hours. Alot of other people complaining about this too saying it becomes Battlefield/CoD.
If you're looking for PvP

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Survive and Thrive! Kill or Be Killed! Any cliche saying you can think of in regards to survival apply here. Is it the most realistic survival game out there? Probably not. But imagine this:

You've just spent countless hours harvesting materials and avoiding dangerous cliffs, wolves, bears and even radiation. You finally find your way back home after being lost in the dark for the last 20 minutes. By your sleeping bag you place your large wooden storage crate which holds everything you have to your name... then you hear it. The feint footsteps grow louder. At this point, the adrenaline within you takes over.  Even the slightest sound begins to make you breathe heavy.  What was that clicking noise?" you ask yourself. The light from a flashlight mounted upon a gun stares directly into your eyes and into your very soul.  In almost an instant you find yourself not within a finely crafted base
date: but within a tomb you have worked so hard to seal yourself within. You have a bow
hoursPlayed: some raw chicken

votesTotal: this silence is maddening. "Hello?!" you cry out. "Is someone out there?". Just as you are at the intersection of "what do I do?" and "where can I go?" you hear a loud "YOOOOOHOOOOOOOO!!!" coming from outside.  Your heart sinks. Your sweaty palms now grip what little you can feel of your mouse. A quick rememberance of playing minecraft on your favorite server flashes in your mind.  But gone are the days of punching trees and finding glorious diamonds. Gone are the days of advanced red stone technology and crafty agricultural designs. No. Here in rust

Last time I've played this game, there was zombies in it.
They did remove them.

Now, we have bears and wolf attacking us, which is ok.
Problem is.. there's not so many bears and wolf.
This game needs more challenge.

Yes it's a PVP game.
Yes you will make friend and you will for sure make ennemies, which is what gives you an actual challenge.. killing peoples and not getting killed!

But that's it.

I know this game is still not a finished product and I hope it will get better. I'm sure it will.. you know why?

Because now the game as better graphics, better crafting method/materials, randomly generated maps, new weapons (melee, gun etc.) , you can even spawn a sleeping bag to a friend so he can teleport next to you! NO NEED TO SEARCH EACH OTHERS FOR YEARSSS .. just joking.. but you get the point.

All in all, this game is good, I can even say it will become GREAT but it takes time and I understand that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a survival game. You will die. You will lose everything you worked for. The players in this game are not afraid to rub salt in the wound. Not only will they kill you on sight, they will laugh and taunt at you and tell you that you are worthless, and will make every effort to find your fresh-spawned butt so that they can just kill you on sight again. Expect all of these to happen within your first 10 hours of gameplay in Rust.

It doesn't matter if this game will come out of Early Access. It will still be a survival game in its core. You must be prepared to lose everything you worked for in a blink of an eye. If you get angry easily, or if you have a job or going to school, then this game is not for you because you need an hour or two of initial gameplay JUST to be situated, even with a friend.

Why do I have 500+ hours of gameplay and am still writing a negative review, you ask? Because I believe I am literally insane. Every week or so, I just wake up and say Hey
date: maybe Rust will be fun today!" But no. It never is fun.\n\nI've had groups hunt me down
hoursPlayed: for sport. I've had 5-6 rude players pickaxe my measly stone-walled base with armored doors for fun. I've had "friends" who would betray me for resources after working together. And the worst part is that I'll launch this horrible game in the next 2-3 weeks so that I can re-live the pain

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First 5 hours of Rust is gathering resources, hunting, building a shelter and surviving. Then after you get a house with a bed and some weapons it turns into a sh**ty free for all FPS.
The community is filled with kiddos and Russians that don't speak English even on non Russian servers, not because they can't but because they're massive cu*ts (A.K.A typical Russians). The only reason I've got 42 hours on record is because I enjoyed killing kiddos and Russians I mentioned before.
However Rust doesn't have much to offer other than PvP as the only NPCs it has are animals that get stuck everywhere and gathering resources is just hitting trees and rocks.
So why am I recommending this game? Well, unlike other early access survival games Rust gets updated frequently and the updates are pretty big. A lot of things have changed since the game has been released and there's more changes coming so as long as the game is alpha and the price doesn't go up I'd say it's worth buying. My rating is 7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

♥♥♥♥ early access games. Early access is a scam and anyone itching to buy into early access games should not do it, even if the games cycle is at a low point, which I think is what spawned this abomination in the first place. I'm not even sure its a good idea for game developers to put their games out as early access. Out of all my friends who own this game, (11 is not a high test pool to be fair) the highest amount of time played on this game is 18 hours. I'm giving Rust the brunt of my aggravation but this was the game I thought had the best potential and so I'm using it as the best example of why early access is a bad idea as a business model.

Servers for this game refresh all the time. Why? Because once a tribe has built their fortress and geared to the max its impossible for new players to get a foothold in the world. If you die in this game- you are likely to lose everything, especially if you die in your base. This encourages server abandonment and loss of interest in the game. Thats the worst thing about this game- theres no achievement no matter how long you toil at it.

The second worst thing about it is the fauna. Smaller game are completely indecipherable in the weeds that cover most of the off road map until you're standing on top of them. Everything else like bears and wolves have a similar camoflage when standing in cover and their aggro range is predictable and robotic. They have zero AI- they are automatons in wildlife skin clothing.

Third and fourth are tied for the absolute horror of your avatar and its postal 2 grade animations. Every player looks like Maynard James Keenan and they skip across the landscape like Army Men- absolutely no pitch or yaw or realistic movements. You crouch to hack at a lump of ore sticking out of the ground with a rock or a wood handled stone hammer (and these ore veins poke out of the landscape like zits on a teenagers cheek)- and the material gets whittled away in goofy chunks.

Its clear what the motive behind the game was by what the dev's got right- spot on gun mechanics and sound. Whoever did the sound for this game knows what an automatic rifle sounds like when its being reloaded- cheap and plastic. The sound of a sniper round chirping across a moonlit landscape is sufficiently creepy. And the sighting and firing has the stink of realism as well, but in this game you can't have your cake and eat it too- although bullets are appropriately deadly no matter what your armor- you may find yourself firing at an opponent who has the movement capabilities of an insect or UFO.

This game wants to be ultra realistic in its approximation of sub-modern warfare and it wants to be minecraft at the same time. It could have done better for itself if it hadn't lured gamers with the promise of completion down the road. Now that its all that closer- I don't know a single person who is interested in it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very unique game in the sense that it has features that you would see in a multitude of other games.
Heck, even the devs said it was inspiried by DayZ, Minecraft and other games.

So what does that mean?

Well, its a survival game. You risk it all by going out into the wild, from being attacked by bears and wolves, or other players trying to survive.

Survival of the fittest is the name of the game.



But, as with any alpha, there are problems.

Few being - alot of hackers out there.
and when i say alot... i mean ALOT.

Gameplay wise? This has kept me glued to my screen.

Would i recommend it? Yes & No
It is almost impossible at this point to play a game due to the hacks.

You can spend hours upon hours just to lose it all to a speed hacking aimbotter...

It is an amazing game, hackers will be phazed out as much as possible down the line, nothing is ever perfect but, this game has alot of potential and on top of that if you have ever played garry's mod, it is created by the same people.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was fun.
WAS fun.

I bought this game when it first came up on steam, and I loved it. (Legacy players would know)
I played it with my friends and was sadly dissapointed when the newer version came out. It looks great, and the blueprint system is still really good, but it is time consuming, time that I never had.

If you can play this everyday then good for you. I never could, only on weekends because my week was filled with other crap. If you don't have friends or clanmembers who play 24/7 then you're constantly fearing for your safety (in the game of course)

That's another thing. While the idea is great and it's not going to get abandoned anytime soon, if you're not in a clan, well then you're at a loss.

All the wipes the servers are doing to prevent clans from becoming so powerfull they'll rule the RUST steam forum page, they are causing other players, who are in it for the building and crafting, to lose weeks of progress.

With all that said, if you don't find the above reasons a problem, then feel free to buy it, it is a fun game, I just lost the love for it.

PS.
This review does not reflect the official servers, I'm from South Africa so I could never connect (I know it's depressing).
This is just my opinion on the User created servers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello everybody! It's been a while since I've written a review, and this review is certainly late for the party. I've been playing since legacy, so I think my opinions are valid for such a time requiring game. Anyways, off to the review!
NOTE: I will be reviewing experimental, because it has grown enough to be considered the main game.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Optimization: This game is generally well optimized on its own, but it can be unreliable at times because your framerate also relies on the server host. Other than that, this game can run on all current PCs, but to run it on lesser ones you must also lower your graphics(as expected). (9/10)

Graphics: The game looks amazing for what it used to look like back in the 'Legacy' version of the game. I'll find myself completely absorbed and immersed because of the atmosphere this game introduces through the sunsets, the views, and the changes in screen overlay depending on the scenery. However, there are still some shading and shadow issues, which can ruin far terrain sometimes. (8/10)

Gameplay: The game is very fun, don't get me wrong, but I feel that it lacks in certain areas. It is time consuming and difficult to build a base good enough to let you sleep and go about the week, let alone protecting yourself from larger raid-clans and dealing with building decay. From this, it becomes very tedious and the overall result makes you sad to go back to it. In the end, you do have some good memories colaborating with the community, which is why I give this section a (7/10).

Originality: Everyone likes an original game, don't they? Well sometimes you have to borrow assets from other games to make said game original. Rust takes most of its communal elements from concepts used (and poorly delivered) in DayZ, and then combines it with other more sandbox like games to create a truly original game. You'll find yourself in wars, disputes, and towns because of the community colaboration's odd concoction with the sandbox elements. In the end, I think this game gave me some unique memories that I'll never forget. (10/10)

Social Ease and Affect: My special category for this game is social ease and affect. By this, I (of course) don't mean how many players have social deficits. Rather, I am judging how the game allows and effects communication with fellow players. Anyways, the microphone compatability along with other people being able to manipulate you when you're offline really adds a sense of realism when it comes to social interaction. You'll find yourself having similar social disputes you'd have in real life, just on a more paleolithic scale. Social interaction is easy, as it is just the hit of the V button. Also, mouths moving when words come out adds a nice touch. (10/10)

The total score of this game is an 88/100, or about a 9/10. Basically, that means it is rising far above most AAA games and is DEFINETLY worth your time, if you have a lot to spare of course.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In the few years this game has been in early access it's core gameplay is still the complete same:

This game is ruled by those who sleep the least, the longer you stay on the more you'll get, seems fair BUT:
-As soon as you log off you will be killed by sleepless chinese people.
-Super-clans still rule the servers, huge groups that abuse the game in one way or another will ruin the server for everyone else.
-Modded servers are utterly pointless, you log on, type /kit whatever and get the gear it would take days to get otherwise.
-Modded servers are hugely unfair as you don't even need a door to your base because you can teleport.
-Community servers are unstable and run like trash
-The game still runs at less than 60fps compared to other better looking games which run fine.
-The devs seem to think that the combat is mostly melee based with their additions of swords and other objects, this simply isn't the case. A gun can easily destroy an entire horde of people of swords and that will never change
-The game has more russians than counter strike
-KOS Community, no suprise there.
-Early access for about 2-3 years
-The mother of all node slapping resource gathering survival games
-Hackers run rampant, despite the anti-cheat.
-You will lose hours of work while you sleep
-Player encounters only ever happen on the shores
-The netcode simply isn't good enough for indoor combat, bullets seem to curve around walls and you can hit people who aren't there
-A shot to the face will be stopped by some foil on your face
-The cost to raid a base is huge compared to the cost to build a base
-Guns don't feel satisfying to use, it's like shooting a slingshot of dust
-All the cool stuff added to the game will take you days to acquire because of the blueprint system
-Due to the KOS community things such as villages and other interesting player encounters are entirely absent.
-Stopping raiders simply takes a tonne of doors, nothing elaborate like traps, just some pickaxe-proof wooden doors.

I don't see the appeal of being slain while you sleep.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So as a player since the legacy version of rust here is my review. The legacy version was horrible, gameplay was too simple and too easy. Hackers everywhere and no way to stop them. Thankfully Garry noticed all of the flaws in the unity version that was used in the legacy version and decided to remake rust on a more up to date unity engine.

I loved the new rust as it came out. Everything ran great, the gameplay was flawless, and it gave me hundreds of hours of gameplay with my friends and community to make giant bases and wage war on other groups. Recently however (last 4-5 months) it has become impossible to play. The performance has got so bad that i get an average of 8 FPS. And i got a computer that can max out everything on ultra settings and get over 100+ fps. Yes i have older hardware but 2 GTX 680's getting 10 FPS on a sandbox shooter is just wrong.

Garry and the team have countlessly noted that their performance sucked. And it would be fixed this week, next week, next month, in 2 months, in 3 more weeks, etc. As i continued to wait, and wait. It was months that i could not play the game with my friends. Months i could not play something i paid for.

The more stuff they update and the more content they add it seems to only make the game worse. Every single update they have done my FPS has got worse and worse. I am a pretty patient person but when i got to wait more than 6 months for a optimization fix that still has not been released. Nope.

The game is great, addictive, and the weekly updates is nice. However the players are toxic, finding friends to game with on here is nearly impossible as everyone just shoots you in the face and insults you or stands outside your home and threaten to kill you in real life and hack/ddos" your computer unless you give them your stuff. I am one of those players that tried very hard to be friendly
recommended: help new people with gear and show them how to play
hoursPlayed:
only for them to use the very bow and arrow i gave them to kill me.

Garry/Facepunch/Rust Team need to realize that 80%+ of their players have older hardware. And a lot of them have nVidia. I have tried playing this on my AMD computer and the FPS difference is sickening. It seems like they are providing performance support for their own choice of hardware and the rest of them can go shove it.

if this games performance is fixed i may change my review but as of now thats all ig ot to say."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I spent about 2 hours looking for a rock, killed a wolf and got chased off by some bloke with a hatchet. Legged it and managed to craft a shelter and a campfire then cooked food. Survived a night.

Was back out early morning, made a door for my shelter. Felt great! But needed to go find that elusive rock. Looked for a while as a bunch of fellow brits argued like a set of married fannies.

And then it happened.

In just one moment.

Everything went cold.

I fell.

I fell far enough to cause bleeding!! And I had used my last Medkits to heal myself after that wolf job.

Panic set in, I needed something. ANYTHING! Too stop the bleeding! But I only had 30 health left.

That was it.

I was done guys.

And in those last few seconds of acceptance.

I saw it.

That one elusive rock shining in the morning sunlight. I walked towards it, hand outstretched.

It was beautiful.

And everything went dark.

The emotions I experienced when I was a noob on the legacy version was totally unreal! Fear, rage, anger, devastation.. The list goes on!

This is the best game I have ever or ever will purchase.

Early Access Review

RUST is one of the most addictive fun games I have ever played.

It contains a big element of ownership as you build your own houses in different territories, which you have to farm materials for around in the world. With these kind of materials you are also able to craft weapons to defend yourself and your territory or even try to take over someone elses by force if you choose to!

Rust is truly unique, there is a lot of different online survivor games, however nothing compares to what RUST is.

The playstyle is entirely up to you, be an underdog and try to take down the big guns or become one of the big groups and withstand attacks on your territory!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

IMO probably the best current and most promising early access Survival game on Steam.  Rust has all of the necessary elements already in the game for a solid Survival game and is only adding to that pool with every update.  I highly recommend you check out the Dev Blog which is updated every Thursday.

The Good...

-Updates every week
-Developers care about cheaters and ban them constantly if correctly reported (check twitter @rusthackreport)
-Rewarding gameplay (pvp is important, resources are crucial and every encounter gets your heartrate going)
-Extremely fun crafting/build system (and is still growing with more options for players)
-Unique biomes that impact what resources are most available (where you decide to try and live matters)
-Combat is brutal and has a high skill cap (practice makes perfect but there is always someone better)
-Support for Twitch Streamers already in early access
-Optional cosmetics are available
-UI is easy to use and understand considering how deep and broad it is
-Game is HARD (might turn off casual players) but rewards those seeking something more in your face
-Optimisation is ongoing and always getting better
-Audio work is solid both world ambience and weaponry

The Bad...

-Really hard to solo, you have to play a lot smarter if you are trying to play alone.  Bigger groups have an advantage
-Not really new player friendly, make sure you read some guides before you get started because otherwise you are bound to be completely lost as there are no real ingame tutorials or hints on what you should be doing
-AI for animals is very stupid, but the roadmap plan for them should change that in 2016
-Weapons IMO are changed too often, I understand it's early access though so can't knock them too hard for this.

Conclusion...

Rust rewards players seeking a deep hardcore experience Survival game.  The building/crafting system is deep, robust, and ever growing with more updates planned.  The frequency I see the game updating, dishing out bans for cheaters, amount of new content being added all tell me the developer really cares about their game and it is only going to keep getting better.  While Rust might not be for everyone, it does not try to pretend to be anything other than what it is, a brutal, challenging, unforgiving game where you can be riding on cloud nine having a really strong base, only to have a crew roll up and take it all away in a matter of minutes if their offense is better than your planned defense.  I've not had time to put a whole lot of time into Rust just yet but in the little I have and hundreds of hours I've watched my favorite Twitch streamers play I have a lot of praise for Rust and what it has already been able to accomplish.  Knowing that this is still in early access and is already such a solid experience, I can't wait to see where this game is a year from now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is Early Access done right!

Been playing since day 1, and it's been quite an adventure. First, the game is wildly addictive and fun. I play on my own low population server since most players are jerks. I'm hoping they add in some more environmental threats and NPCs to give people something to do other than kill and grief eachother.

Within the last few months the game has finally surpassed legacy in playability and fun. The choice Facepunch made to basically start over is paying off. We're starting to see new stuff added much more frequently and the Workshop is really cool if you're into cosmetic items.

The game is much more tedious if you're a solo player, but it's also rewarding to build a whole base by yourself.

Every time I play I'm struck by how beautiful the game has become. Just running across the island lets you see so many amazing landscapes.

Finally, I love the weekly dev blogs. I've learned so much about the development process from keeping up with this game. Facepunch does the best job of listening to the community while filtering out all the idiots that are constantly complaining. This game is definitely worth the price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To start it off you guys are most likely wondering if this game is worth buying and what it has to offer, from bad to good.
Let's start with bad:
*Updates are fair but could be faster for what little they add
*Lots of death (Also part of the good :D)
*Lots of jerks
*A fair sum of bugs

Now the good:
*The death and grind combine to surprisingly make the game a refreshing experience every time you die, with costs, but these costs give you new goals that make you want to continue playing the game further.
*Advanced building mechanics
*Great FPS mechanics (except for the drop on some of the guns, an AK shouldn't have an insane amount of drop at only 80 meters and should probably do a little bit more damage but cost more)
*C4!!! The raiding! A blood pumping, heart racing feeling you really don't get over.
*The asthetics, this game is a really beautiful game.
*The events, I've had so many memories on this game that I won't be forgetting for awhile.

With all of this to mind, the pros beat the cons and my personal opinion to this, is that this game is epic, just get it.
9/10 - (10/10 if updates would come sooner.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rust is a game that combines DayZ, Minecraft and a little bit of Stalker.
It’s currently in Alpha, but it is already a lot of fun to play, especially with friends or just alone.

The community of Rust can be harsh and ruthless sometimes, Since most people will shoot you on sight, but there are also people that are friendly and help each other.

Is ‘Player versus Player’ nothing for you or just too hard? Then just join one of the few hundred ‘Player versus environment’ servers. And play without anyone trying to smash your head in with a hatchet or blow your head off with a shotgun.

Gather resources, craft, hunting, base building it’s all in the game.

Definitely worth the money, just a warning; the game can be somewhat addictive.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=216240928

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**UPDATED REVIEW AS OF 6/1/2015**

I played Rust again seriously for the first time in almost a year tonight, and it was great. Now, I'm not sure just how great it was since I didn't run into any players that weren't sleeping, but I'm sure I was having fun in some way. The house building mechanics are definitely more improved now, but I feel like it was ten times harder to navigate and find my friend. The severe lack of landmarks across a majority of Hapis had me searching for nearly two hours. Also, we just up and find C4 blueprints now? I feel like I've been cheated out of my time/effort from the old days when hunting a C4 down just to copy it to a schematic was like end game stuff, and now this? Damn. Overall, I just hope this game will feature less kids next time I get on and there's more than my friend and I on our server we chose. It'll be really awesome to meet all of the new and interesting players that will KOS because they've swrorn to role play as bots from a late-90's fps games like Quake.

**OLD REVIEW**
If I had payed $5 more, I could have just bought 7 Days To Die Instead when I had originally blown $20 to buy this. I regret nearly every hour put into this early access game so far when I look back at it. I'm even referring to the hours that were spent in laughter of stupid things company and I were doing. It was all for naught, and Facepunch only updates this game once every so months now. I think I invested a better $20 into Valkyria Chroncles just the other day.

Point: only buy this game if you feel like you hate yourself, and can't afford an extra $5-$10 for a better early access game. Actually, just do yourself a favor, spend under $10, and get 100% Orange Juice instead. That seems to go on sale every other week for less than $4 to boot. It's more playable with friends minus wanting to pound nails into your male reproductive organ.

Also, the community is full of annoying kids. That's the worst part about it.

**UPDATE**
The meta-game isn't fun either. It's just like playing the real game, except now it's just a text adventure with kids.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While being a modern creation, I feel Rust has captured a piece of what it was like to survive in the ancient past. Not from a technical point of view, but tapping into a deep survivalistic part of our brains. Tension is very high while you travel around collecting resources and try to stay alive, and it feels ...right. Almost a social experiment. You get used to being on constant alert as everything you worked for could be taken away by raiders at any moment. Is that speck a person? Is that person a friend or foe? Am I ready?

As another reviewer mentioned - this game will put you through the gamut of emotions while offering a fun survival game experience for a mere $22. With some ups and downs in development - IMO Rust is now on its way to becoming a great game. I recommend.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDropped into this mysterious world of Rust, there I was lost in the wild with only a rock to weigh me down. As the sun set on this world devoid of humans a flicker of light caught my eye. There it was at last! Humanity! A sign of life! Quickly I made my way over to them where I was then held at gun point by two players. I begged for a sign of mercy, I explained that I was merely a lone survivor looking to group up to take on the world. It took some convincing but under their wing I went. They taught me how to build my first house. They found me food, clothing and weapons, all things I so desperately needed to survive. How ever food was scarce, ammo was low and people were slowly moving in on our territory. I quickly learned that this relationship wouldn’t work, I had to survive. It was me or them and I was playing to live, because of this I had to do one of the hardest things, take the other two out, with the very gun that was given to me! It was me or them and I had to survive. Its situations like this that make this game so worth while, to observe how other people act towards one another when pitted against starvation and limited resources. The results will scare you. Rust is a survival open world crafting game that is currently available for PC and in this players are dropped into a world with no direction, no objective, no help. You are simply put into the world and forced to learn. For some the game is a lot to take in and I can admit that even I was overwhelmed in the beginning but you grow into it, and once familiarize with your world, you get lost in it. Rust is a time consumer in that you are always prone to attack, players work with one another or work against one another in trying to take the resources that you have worked so hard to obtain. Rust is a high risk high reward game in where a death results in the loss of everything putting you back at square one. Its not for the faint of heart but a definite worth of the 20$ price tag it holds. I find myself discovering new areas, people and structures in Rust everyday that keeps me coming back. I would definitely recommend Rust, not only for the game play that is easily learned but the feeling the game gives you when you set out to raid another playing and the adrenaline rush that comes from knowing that you might not come back from this alive.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rust is a game about survival. But that takes time. Initially, it's just about death. It's about freezing to death, and starving to death, being shot to death and getting bitten to death; occasionally mixing things up a little by slipping on a warm radiation coat and fading faster than your faith in humanity after being stabbed in the back by a supposed friend's hatchet. Sometimes you get gored to death. Other times, bored to death. It's not easy, surviving post-apocalyptic civilisation with nothing but a rock - especially when your enemies have guns, and double-especially in a game that makes you work just to earn a pair of basic trousers.

Even this early into development, Rust's mix of DayZ and Minecraft (the easiest comparison, though Wurm Online is more apt) has won it no shortage of fans - some of them not even psychopaths, hackers and trolls on the hunt for new victims to murder and mock over voice chat. It's the kind of game that's less a shooter than an engine designed to tell stories. Those stories are mostly, as ever, in the field of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥om, but there's scope for some humanity amongst all the pranks and murder. It's also a world that focuses on demanding effort rather than promising to reward it: starting players out naked and hungry and alone, dangling the potential of going on to build forts, craft weapons, and finally savour the air at the top of the food chain.

I bought Rust back when zombies were a thing, the game was beautiful, like an uncut diamond. It had so much potential but the developers have changed the game and not for the better, I played today for the first time in a year and the game felt even less finished than previously. The graphics are better but the whole design, UI, controls have become clunky and guttered. There was less hacking but everyone seemed to have get a hard on for killing people who held nothing but a rock.

Yes Rust is about survival and no rules apply but there it is more fun when there is collaboration not just mindless killing, the backwards step combined with the 12 year olds lusting for killing makes me dislike what Rust has become.

EDIT: Came back after a friend bought the game and tried it out, some new features were interesting and everything looked better however, the graphics are much more intensive though and my computer struggled to handle it. One thing I saw disgusted me though, charging such high prices to 'skin' items.

At the end of the day, still not out of Alpha two years later.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day One: Figured out that Radiation hurts. So do bullets. Oh, and Wolves, Bears, Snow and Water. Realised my genitals were out, and incredibly detailed. Died more than I lived, so made a friend join me before I did something incredibly smart like put my sleeping bag underwater.

Base One: 10 Hours to build, Up in mountains for sneaky stealth, 10 minutes to get rocketed to the ground.

Base Two: 8 Hours to build, close to new arch enemy crew, logged off for the night, woke up naked on a beach.

Base Three: Swam to an Island away from danger, Recruited people from the server who shared equal distaste for Arch Enemies, Became 7 Strong. 20 hours in, we stealthed into enemies base of operations and by some strange twist of fate found their weapon & ammunition stockpiles, and managed to deauthorise them from building in their own base. Now we're just waiting for them to come online so we can laugh at them.

10/10 - would waste the first 30 hours of gameplay building and being blown up again.

---

Seriously though, BUY RUST. It's amazing. Every element of the game is great. Sure, it's like every other Early Access Survival game, but it's also SO MUCH MORE. Join a server close to you that's decently populated.

Learn the ropes, make friends (lol jks, they'll probably spear you in the back more than actually help you), Plan your base location strategically, make frantic nudie runs into radiation-plagued towns for precious blueprints and loot, Watch from afar to learn how your enemies operate, Mount full-scale warfare on them (While they're offline, No one in Rust likes a fair fight), and either Dance around naked in victory, or retreat to fight another day (provided you survive longer than 10 minutes, and manage to limp away with your gear and dignity still intact).

I've found it nigh on IMPOSSIBLE to get an early or good nights sleep since I first launched Rust. That was Friday, and It's now Friday again. I've injected 50 hours into the game in a week. I work full time. Rust is more important than real life. You'll definitely find yourself logging in to Check up on the base" at 10pm and still be running around gathering resources and killing Nekkids at 8am (Welcome to me
recommended: But the damn game. Watch me play it on youtube at eksalegaming."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first discovered Rust about a year ago, it was broken, with bad combat mechanics, laggy, and extremely poorly optimized, but overall a very fun experience. A year later it's broken, with bad combat mechanics, laggy, still poorly optimized AND it's almost unplayable for solo players or even small teams. So the only positive point for me (fun experience) went down the drain.

In other words, with the new features added these last couple of months that can only be built and maintained if you're part of a 5-6 men group or more, Rust became almost unplayable for casual solo players, including myself. I can't really be bothered nor do I have the time to commit to this game to such an extent. Organized teams get most airdrops (which contain op gear), helicopter drops as well (which will soon contain exclusive parts for turrets according to the devblog), build large bases with space for all the high capacity furnaces and other processing facilities, quarries etc.

As a solo player, you can't get online and just gather some resources, build a small house, put a couple of furnaces and start collecting stuff - no, you'll get raided as soon as some team's scout spots your house and decides to tear it down with a couple of C4 charges (that you, as a solo player, don't have access to).

One last point: the community. Russians, children, hackers, sociopaths, you name it - Rust has it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Date purchased: April 21, 2014
Date Reviewed: Jan 7, 2016
Review Updated:May 6, 2016
Time played legacy: about 20 hours
Time played new Rust: 100+ hours

Graphics:
It feels like the game almost can't decide whether it is cartoony or realistic, but I know one thing for sure and that one thing is that there is absolutely no personality to it. The visuals are pretty much like the opposite of legacy Rust. Legacy Rust's graphics were pretty bad, yet they had a tremendous amount of personality. New Rust's graphics are OK at best when they are turned up in comparison to other modern games, but they feel like they have no personality or original atmosphere.

The graphics on the terrain are pretty sharp, some of the visual effects are impressive and the lighting is great. The game looks good when you are standing still. But when moving, there is very clear, ugly texture pop in, trees look horrendous at any distance, and you can see blotchy shadows just appear out of no where. It all just feels very unstable and super sloppy. Graphics just don't feel crisp or smooth at all.

Sound:
It's still in alpha, so I'm not going to be too hard on it. But don't expect any beautiful orchestrated music or realistic sounds in general. Practically every sound in the game sounds like a pitched up or pitched down version of each other. One thing I do admire about the sound design is the realism of gunshots. The pop of the muzzle actually causes you to fear the person who is shooting at you.

The HUD sounds are nice and I can appreciate the fact that crouching mutes the walking noise allowing for a stealthy playstyle.

Gameplay:
Gunplay in particular where Rust excels. The gunplay is very realistic and challenging even if it can be unbalanced from time to time. Melee fighting is also pretty fun when it does occur. Crafting is a rather repetitious and grindy task, and can get old quickly if you don't have a lot of patience. There is almost no sense of discovery, as procedural generation creates very generic and repetitive scenes. The first few times you play, the post-apocalyptic feel will feel great, but sooner or later you will find yourself sighing at the sight of an abandoned town or partly destroyed bridge. You collect blueprints and items from barrels, which spawn comepletely randomly. This adds to the grindy feel of the game and subtracts the discovery feel even more.

The game feels very empty at the current state and it feels like once you see all the game has to offer, the game just becomes very useless. It's basically the same cycle over and over again, not allowing for variation.
Spawn--->Collect items--->Build a base--->Loot monuments--->Get raided--->Repeat
There currently is not much PvE which really hurts the replay value of the game, but I am looking forward to seeing what Facepunch has in store as far as PvE goes. The entire game is basically a large battlefield at it's current state.

The AI is godawful and is possibly the game's biggest flaw. Bears and wolves run through landscapes, aren't reactive to anything and have horrible animations. There is very few variations in AI, and all of the models look pretty bad. It's embarrassing and disappointing how Facepunch has yet to even address fixing this when the AI has been this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ since new Rust was introduced.

Community:
Rust has gotten a reputation for having an absolutely horrendous community. And it has that reputation for a reason. The community is probably worse than any other game community combined. Hackers run rampant, people will be ♥♥♥♥♥ for no reason, people kill you for no reason, ect. The game's community is one major flaw that I'm afraid the dev's can't fix.

Stability & Optimization:
Like many other early access games, this game runs like a nightmare. There isn't much else to say. If you plan on buying this game, make sure you don't have any sub-par hardware or else you are going to suffer. There are tons of bugs, many of which get fixed relatively fast though.

Game Support:
For anybody that is unfamiliar with Facepunch's support, it is pretty mediocre. All I have to say about that.

Verdict:
Rust has a very strong foundation to be a great game. It has some good ideas, they just aren't executed well at all. With proper tweaking and removal of the grindy feel, I think this could quite possibly be one of the better games in recent release though. But the entire game still just feels very incomplete and sluggish at the stage it's in. If you are debating on buying, save your money. Wait until the game nears completion that way you will really feel that you got your money's worth. I honestly can't say that I would recommend this game at the state it's at.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While still in development, Rust already has many things that can hook you up.

It's one of those survival games that early access is full of, but this one is good.
This is one of games that was inspiration for many of those games.

Rust ( now called Rust Legacy) was the first version i took my hands on. It had zombies, which have since been scrapped.
It had pretty good building system, and it was fun to build huge house or fortress with your friend, while still defending it, so that other players wouldn't raid it.

Raiding, one big part of the game. What is yours, is mine. After airdrop, you might have been lucky, and gotten recipe for C4 crafting. Then you would've crafted few explosives from hardly earned materials. Then, waited for a while. Gathered your group, and silently found best entrance to enemy's fortress. You raided their home, stole all you needed, and ran. Next day, this might happen to you too.

Rust Legacy, the old version of the game, is still available to play, if you so desire. It's basic survival at it's finest;
Spawn in a forest, start chopping trees, build your first shed. Start gathering materials to build bigger home.
After a while, you'll start getting metal materials, which is more durable, and thus harder to raid by others.
You should have crew, and each member should have a weapon. For first, melee weapons will do. But later on, you'll find weapons, or recipes to craft them. Once you'r crew has those weapons, you can start raiding, or create huge castle.
But that's pretty much what legacy is all about, it just ends. After a while, there is nothing more to do, and if you don't want to start from beginning, or keep raiding, it's all you've got.

Developers saw this, and started building Rust from the very beginning,
This is now called Rust Experimental. While it still lacks some features that Legacy has, it's going to be greater, bigger, more awesome in every way.

Experimental has better graphics, if you care about those. It has randomly generated map, and improved crafting.
Some day, it will be better than at the moment, but it is still fun. For now, if your'e looking for more complete version, I would play Legacy. Every update to Experimental adds features, and soon it will be the better version. And boy it will be good. This is one of the gems of early access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's one of the best survival games currently available even though it's still in Early Access. It's developing quite fast.

What's good about this game?
- Graphics (Really amazing graphics, weather and effects.)
- Sound (Realistic and atmospheric sound. It's really necessary in order to get that real" feeling.)
- Gameplay (There is a lot of things that you can do. Craft
hoursPlayed: raid
voteText:
kill & meet people. What's really important is that it doesn't get boring fast. Actually I'm still not bored of it after 150 hours.)
- Option to choose between playing Legacy version & new version.
- Good anti-cheat in new version compared to Legacy version.

What's bad about this game?
- Playing alone. It's really hard to play alone because 90% of people on server are in clans and you really have to spend a lot of time collecting resources and trying to build a safe base. Every single base is raidable but when you are alone it's hard to make a big and "safe" one.
However take in mind that this is an open-world multiplayer game with a large community and because of that it's really easy to find people to play with together. But some people love to be lone wolves and survive alone.

Overall
It's a really good game. As I previously said there is plenty of things that you can do. I don't know what to write anymore. You just have to play the game and experience it for yourself.

Just a little tip: If you want to stay away from people
